en: Interview with Cara Parker, social worker with the Helen Ross McNabb Center in Sevierville. Parker discusses the ways in the which the agency provided assistance to survivors of the fires, as well as elaborating on some common problems that these individuals and families faced. She also talks about how different facets of the community were brought together in addressing these needs. This is a representative quote from the interview: "The biggest way, from a mental health center perspective, is the decreased stigma for seeking mental health treatment."

Interview with Cara Parker, social worker with the Helen Ross McNabb Center in Sevierville. Parker discusses the ways in the which the agency provided assistance to survivors of the fires, as well as elaborating on some common problems that these individuals and families faced. This is a representative quote from the interview: "The biggest way, from a mental health center perspective, is the decreased stigma for seeking mental health treatment."

How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Could you talk about what drew you to social work?
Can you tell us about the Helen Ross-Mcnabb Center?
What were your roles at the center before the fire?
Can you share your impressions of Sevier County and the community?
What do you remember of the days leading up to the fire?
Did the center close any? When did people start coming in for fire related assistance?
Initially, were you only hearing from existing clients?
Can you talk about the discussions around applying for the grants?
Around January was when the grant took effect, what was your role?
Without specifics, what was it like meeting families in their homes? What was the vibe in the community?
Were you doing multiple trainings and bringing more people onto the team?
Was the center seeing and increase or decrease from individuals seeking assistance?
Can you talk about the crisis programs and how they were an evolution of the process?
Around what time did you start shifting into educating the community?
What did this community education look like?
How did the community respond to this?
What changes have you seen in the past years?
For yourself as a mental health specialist, how has this affected your work?
What are some examples of ways that this shaped the community?
Do you feel that a lot of those connections that were made have remained?
As someone who grew up in Southern Appalachia, what have you seen for the relationship between these people and mental health?
Had the Helen Ross McNabb Center prepared for disasters like this before the fire? How have preparations changed after?
Had the Helen Ross McNabb Center prepared for disasters like this before the fire? How have preparations changed after?
Is there anything else that you would like to add?

seo.title: Interview with Cara Parker, 2019-12-12 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
